moves.1. e3 e6 2. d4 c5 3. Nf3 Nc6: A strange opening, but it seems to work.
moves.4. Bd2 Nf6 5. c4 d5 6. Qa4 Bd7 7. b3: A mistake; there is no retreat for the white queen.
moves.7... cxd4: Definitely should have played Nxd4 instead. (Queen trap!)
moves.8. b4: Stephen, now noticing that his queen is in peril, urges his team to give her an escape square.
moves.10... Rb8 11. Qa6 Rb6: The queen gets pushed around while my rook develops.
moves.12. Qa4 Bc5 13. exd4 Nxd4: Right now my pieces slowly creep over to attack the white king.
moves.14. Qd1 Ne4: If I took the f3 knight right away, then if gxf3 my knight could no longer come to e4.
moves.15. Ba5: A bold move; I did not even realize this threat. But I have something better...
moves.15... Rxb1: I told my team: Although this move is risky--and I showed them the variations--often times you have to be risky in chess. I believe we made the best decision.
moves.16. Rxb1: This is Stephen's team's best move, since Qxb1 is met with Qxa5+, Kd1, Nc3+, forking the king and queen; Bxd8 is met with, Bb4+, Nd2(forced), Bxd2#
moves.16... Qxa5+ 17. Nd2 Bb4 18. Qc1: A blunder indeed. All it did was waste a move and make way for mate. Probably best for white is Rb2.
moves.18... Bxd2+ 19. Kd1 Ba4+ 20. Rb3 Bxb3+ 2: Stephen later asked: "What if I didn't take the bishop?" Answer: Mate would still be forced (Qd2#) or if b4 then King move and mate on the next turn (Qc2# or Bd2#).
moves.22... Qa1#: We finished just in time to leave, luckily. I hope you enjoyed our game.
